title: I think i've sorted myself an overhead table!

posts.content:
Whilst having a little look on ebay this weekend I noticed a little red formica table listed as less than 5 miles away. A few measurements by the seller and I drove round to have a look...



I couldn't believe that it was an exact match for my existing red interior! It was 4mm longer and about 5mm narrower than original but I figured it'd be a great place to start. I got it home, unscrewed the legs and (as it was getting dark and I'm impatient) thought I'd try and see how it fits....







I figured it's a great place to start and for a bargain thirty quid got to be better than the piece of mdf in there at the mo.

The plan is to remove the existing table brackets and fit the devon ones for now.

The bus is going in for new panels, flooring, curtains and cushions in a few weeks so i'll be sure to add some ones when the tartan has gone!

Cheers

Scott

Result...
With a little work it could be perfect..
Result
Lovely. Red Formica really is an elite club

Great find. Well pleased for you.

Happy Days eh

The OG table is thicker than just the top and has an oak edging border on all four sides.
I would guess you could use as is or take to a chippy to cut down the excess and then add the wooden edge all round and some ply to add the depth.
I am happy to measure/photo every feature..
Mine on my 64 has very big plates on it..which are steel painted.
You have the plates and the legs...So result. .
G

Graham, thank you. Clymoj kindly sent me some pictures and measurements so I have a good idea of what needs doing. My only fear is the edge chipping when cut. I've read various suggestions including taping the cut or sandwiching in ply. I'm hoping to find a decent carpenter who'll know what to do.

Both of the above could work, but you'd have to be very skilled. A "Router" or a "Spindle Moulder" is probably the best tool for cutting it, or a "Table Saw" with a very fine and sharp blade. If using a saw, I'd cut a tad bigger and use a sharp plane to finish it. Make sure they bond the extra ply on first. But like you say, I'm sure they'd know all this.

Good Luck

When I saw your initial post..I smiled....
That is exactly what a have been doing!
Yours is a classic 60s kitchen table.
I have been looking in the formica covered furniture for ages...Now and again..Yours comes with ready patina and will look great as is...

I keep looking for some fine brown formica using the same search idea,,,,,but no luck so far..
But O did not see your table... so well done..
It will be great as is but with Oak edging and thus a bit more weight would be perficcccck
G
